headline: Gender dominates GOP Ohio Senate debate as Mike Gibbons dismisses women's oppression
author: Haley BeMiller
sentences: Gibbons was addressing questions about a previous interview, in which he said former Ohio Republican Party chair and GOP Senate challenger Jane Timken "barely worked" and insinuated that her money comes from her husband.

U.S. Senate candidate Mike Gibbons said Monday that women were "probably" oppressed when they didn't have the right to vote as he defended previous claims that his only female opponent has never worked.

Haley BeMiller is a reporter for the USA TODAY Network Ohio Bureau, which serves the Columbus Dispatch, Cincinnati Enquirer, Akron Beacon Journal and 18 other affiliated news organizations across Ohio.
State Sen. Matt Dolan used the occasion to criticize Timken's time as party chair, saying Republicans lost Ohio Supreme Court seats now playing a key role in the redistricting process.
The event came days after Gibbons and former state treasurer Josh Mandel sparred on stage during another debate, one of them appearing to use a derogatory term for women as an insult.

Gender takes center stage
Timken is married to former TimkenSteel CEO Ward Timken, Jr. and worked as an attorney and magistrate after graduating from Harvard University.
In a statement Tuesday, she blasted Gibbons' remarks as "misogynistic and anti-women" and said his behavior at recent debates should disqualify him from the race.
Timken is the only woman running in the GOP primary and released an ad earlier this year painting her rivals as "guys who overcompensate for their inadequacies."
Gibbons doubled down on his position Tuesday, saying Ohio needs a senator with experience who isn't "spending family wealth on vanity runs for office."
His comments fueled a larger discussion about women and gender during a debate in Cleveland between the five leading contenders in the GOP primary.

When asked about the ad on Monday, she argued some levity is allowed but said the race is ultimately serious business.
Other candidates on stage Monday swept in to defend Timken and tout their pro-woman credentials as a knock on Gibbons.
"I think when (women) weren’t allowed to vote, they were probably oppressed," Gibbons said during Monday's debate.
